He shaped U.S. taxation strategies during and after the war, drafted Wisconsin's tax laws, and held leadership positions in economic organizations like the National Tax Association and the American Economic Association. Adams also contributed to international fiscal discussions as a member of the League of Nations' fiscal committee. His academic career spanned roles at institutions such as the University of Wisconsin–Madison and Yale, where he advanced political economy studies. His work solidified his legacy as a pivotal figure in 20th-century economic policy.
